abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the Amazon
            Region Protected Areas Project (ARPA) is to expand and
            consolidate the protected areas (PAs) system in the Amazon
            Region of Brazil. The project is the first phase of a
            10-year ARPA program. There are five project components. The
            first component finances the creation of 18 million hectares
            of PAs. Activities include collecting biological, social,
            and economic data on the Amazon region; preparing studies,
            consultations, and proposals; and establishment of the PAs.
            The second component consolidates the new PAs by demarcation
            and land regularizations, basic protection activities, and
            preparation and implementation of management plans. The
            third component establishes an endowment fund for long-term
            sustainability of PAs. the fourth component establishes a
            biodiversity monitoring system and supports analysis of new
            and existing protected areas. This component supports
            training for PA staff. The fifth component supports the
            overall coordination of the various components in the
            Ministry of Environment, the the Brazilian Institute for the
            Environment and Renewable Natural Resources, and the
            Brazilian Biodiversity Fund, and ensures implementation of
            such management activities as preparation of supervisory
            reports or any requests for information by donors,
            preparation of annual operating plans, monitoring and
            evaluation of project activities, procurement and financial
            management, and communication and dissemination activities.
